Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Quick, simple. Met the IT staff and support staff
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Security Guard Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Flint, MI) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: A sit down interview with the sergeant of the campus police. We went over my resume and all my previous job experiences. I was asked if I was currently a student at the university and if I was willing to work around my classes.
Interview Questions: If I had any experience in this job.

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: It is a full weekend where they fly you in. The first night you go to dinner with just graduate students in a relaxed environment. The next day is full of short interviews with faculty members. At night you go to an event for your department of interest with students and faculty. And finally on the next morning, you attend a poster session where you can learn about all departments and programs for students and take a tour of campus.
Interview Questions: What research have you done in the past and what impact could this potentially have?

title: Intern - Hourly Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Michigan in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: It was 3 part interview process with a phone interview first, a group interview, followed by a 1 on 1 . The group interview was a group discussion regarding an article we were told to read before hand and it was followed up with a personality quiz and assessment. We were then brought back to a 1 on 1 interview if we passed the second part.
Interview Questions: Name a time you were faced with adversity and how you overcame it?

title: Student Manager Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Meet with director, it was very easy. As student jobs go this was one of the best. Just got two dollar raises. Showing any initiative brings promotion. Really would highly recommend to any student at the university. Interview was informal. Easy to schedule around classes.
Interview Questions: What do you see yourself doing after graduation

title: Part Time Employment Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: First there was a one on one interview with an architect and manager. Then there was a written exam on a variety of concepts like Java, Database etc. My exam was graded while I was waiting in the conference room. They confirmed that I passed the interview and confirmed my rate.
Interview Questions: What are virtual functions?

title: Senior Human Resources Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: I initially had a brief interview over the phone and then was called back for a panel interview with three peers.  A couple of weeks later I was contacted regarding a panel interview with some of the HR Managers from the various schools the position supports.  There was also an interview with the Director.  The style of interview questions were behavioral based questions.  A writing sample was also requested.
Interview Questions:
-We handle a lot of situations in gray areas.  Can you give us an example of a situation you've dealt with that didn't have a clear cut answer.  
- What area are my skills strongest and what aspect of HR do I have the least experience in.
- Describe a situation in which I had to get a leader a difficult message.
- I was asked to describe a change management initiative in which I was involved and to explain my role.

title: Media Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions: Very relaxed interview process.  I applied online through the University's student employment board, was emailed and had an in person interview with two people 2 days later and was hired 3 days after that.  Questions were a mix of standard ("What are your strength and weaknesses," etc) and tailored to the position (experience with Adobe suite, etc).
Interview Questions: They were all fairly standard.

title: Radiology Resident Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions: Apply through ERAS. Interviews usually from October to January. Just apply like as for any other radiology residency spot. Very approachable faculty and easy interview process. Big emphasis on research and uniqueness. Make sure to follow up after the interview to show interest. Great place to get trained.
Interview Questions: why here.

title: Graduate Student Instructor Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Nov 2012
Interview Descriptions: There wasn't really any interview process.  You just need to specify which course that you're interested in teaching well before(3 months?) the semester actually begins.  They say that they test English skills of international graduate students, but I never was tested.
Interview Questions: It wasn't really a question, but before you actually start GSI-ing. They will ask you to give a sample lecture in front of a bunch of people in a room.  They will give you helpful advice(in other words, they will criticize you! -kidding).

title: Statistician Intermediate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Oct 2012
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview first for an hour, I was short-listed and they called me for an on-site interview. I met with team mates during my second interview. They were friendly. the boss and manager also took me to lunch with one other team member The whole second interview lasted 3-4 hours.
Interview Questions: Lots of technical questions, programming questions

title: Library Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI)
Interview Descriptions: Honestly, I didn't even get interviewed. My sister had a friend who worked in the library, so he basically had me contact his boss, and with his approval his boss said OK right away. I sent in a resume, but there was no interview at all.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: I have worked at this place when I was a student and my coworker introduced this position to me. I applied for the position through the university career website. I included descriptions of research projects, reference names, objectives to achieve through the position as well as resume and cover letter. I had one interview on-site.
Interview Questions: They asked me to show my dissertation work.

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Talked to interested parties and demonstrated experience and research interests.
Interview Questions: Talked about using techniques to best take advantage of mobile processors.

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by email and had two subsequent interviews, one with my boss and one with various members of other labs adjacent to ours. I was contacted within a week of the submission deadline, the interviews were within the next two weeks, and I received a job offer shortly thereafter. I did hear from my references that they were contacted for verification. We also had a couple of times where we met to discuss starting dates and salary.
Interview Questions: What are some ideas you have for future directions in our lab focus?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Most interviews are done two different times. The Prime Investagator (PhD) is present at one of the interviews. Most often they have initiated the area that is being researched and have aacquired the funds for the project.
Interview Questions: Why are you doing research? What are your educational goals? What salary do you expect to receive? How many years of experience in research programs do you have?

title: Leo Lecturer I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Dearborn, MI) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was expecting a typical teaching type interview which it was, but I was also hired on the spot. The interview was laid back and made me feel at ease.
Interview Questions: The most difficult question I find in any teaching interview is how do you handle conflict.

title: Non Administrative Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions: Interview wasn't bad.  This was actually so many years ago that I don't really recall the process too well, but I know others who have interviewed recently and it sounded like the same.  Nowadays I sure they have you do a drug test as well.  Good luck to anyone trying for a job, but don't do ANYTHING your boss does not like past 10 or 20 years or you are out of there.
Interview Questions: The questions were normal, what type of experience and what hours can you work then small talk.

title: CAD Graphic Specialist Associate At the Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions:
Applied through their online system, received a Confirmation of Successful Application back to my email. About 10 days later I received an email to schedule an interview. Had the interview with 3 people (concurrently) that worked at the media center, one of them a manager of same. 

The job was much more straight forward that the description of it in the job posting, it boiled down to printing graphic files on large HP plotters, supervising student doing self-prints, and, working in the coffee shop that was part of the media center. No mention of the coffee shop was in the job posting though it would not have been a deal breaker for me. Very proficient familiarity with current Adobe graphics programs and a very good graphic arts background were in the job listing as was 3D software experience. I had all that though it turned out the 3D experience was not needed at all, hands on assistance for students printing was not part of the job, I assumed it would be. If the student screwed up their printout (low-res files, missing links, etc) they would only be told how to fix the issue, not actually given help on how to do that hands on, if you know what I mean. 

A little bit of an attitude from the manager towards the students though all three principals at the interview were quite nice. The HR rep who was the point person through emails, was not actually at the interview, though that's probably inconsequential. Got a phone call about a week later, from the Media center manager, telling me I didn't get the job. I thanked her. All in all it was very congenial.
Interview Questions: I was shown 3 examples of "bad" printouts to diagnose, that is diagnose the root cause of why they turned out looking bad.

title: Assistant Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Michigan in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: Was contacted via email to come for an interview the following week.  I met with the Director and two high-ranking employees in the department.  They asked me many questions about my work history and education, and experience preparing and writing exams.  They were very concerned with the fact that I did not have teaching experience, which was not required for the job.  I felt that I was very qualified for the job and they didn't like the fact that I wasn't a Michigan alum.
Interview Questions: Why did you not have any teaching experience in graduate school?

title: Statistical Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: Interview involved a half-day of conversations with staff analysts/faculty members.  Lots of questions about academic background and technical skillset.  Short presentation was involved, but pretty informal.  Lots of discussion about development/project management opportunities.  Interview process was a good introduction to the cast of characters I’d ultimately end up working with.  Overall, was pretty laid back.
Interview Questions: What's one example of a challenge you've faced while working on a team previously?  How did you overcome this challenge to accomplish your team's goal(s)?

title: Assistant Director of Campus Recreation Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: It began with a phone interview that lasted about 45 minutes with a hiring committee of 4 people.  From there, I had an in-person interview while at a professional development conference in Anaheim with the same 4 people.  Finally, they flew me on campus for a 2-day long interview.  All in all, it was a very professional interview process that took about 3 weeks from start to finish, which is standard for the position I was applying for.
Interview Questions: What change can you bring to our program?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: Attended a Nursing Open House. Made some contacts, set up interviews for the very next day. Applied to recommended positions and was hired right away.
Interview Questions: What are you looking for in the future?

title: Research Technician Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: The initial application, planning the interview, interviewing, accepting the offer, background check, and HR processing took 2 months. The people and work culture are amazing, very welcoming and helpful.
Interview Questions: Why are you leaving your old position?

title: Graduate Student Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Michigan in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions:
1. Application by online system
2. Professor contacted by E-mail
3. Schedule interview by Skype (for international students)
4. One hour interview for both behavior interview and technical questions: The questions about behavior interview could be found online. The technical questions could vary based on the lab and PI's interests. It's good to look at the lab website and read more review paper in the specific field. It would help a lot.
Interview Questions: The questions overall are easy to answer. However, sometimes the communication quality is so bad that makes the interview difficult because I needed to check the questions several times.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was not by any means extensive. Often, researchers are looking for students to begin immediately. Usually, you just send your resume, cover letter, and a brief background  through the student employment website and then wait for employer to contact you. Some jobs will require an informal interview.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply for this position?

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: they are thorough in the interview process which is satiating know that I was the selected candidate to work there at the time. however, what was discussed in the interview was not exactly the projects that I was targeted to complete.
Interview Questions: what skills does it take to become an excellent analyst?

title: Allied Health Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: I had never been to U of M hospital before and that place is huge!  I followed the directions given to me and finally ended up in a conference room in the basement after wandering around in a sea of hallways down there.  No one in the room, nothing set up in the conference room, no note on the table, hello or welcome to your interview on the whiteboard...nothing.  No cell reception in the basement or phone in the conference room so can't call the department.  Nothing I can do but wait.  Staff finally shows up (late) for the interview.   I could tell 5 minutes in I'm not a good a fit, no way I'm getting this job but gave it my best shot, what the heck why waste an interview it's good practice.  Most panel members seemed to have really uptight personalities, hiring manager downright prickly and defensive.  Standard interview questions, nothing too unexpected.  Drove home thinking I wouldn't take the job even if they offered it to me (which they didn't), I can't work for this team, I'd be miserable.  At least they had the courtesy to let me know about a week later I wasn't chosen.
Interview Questions: Standard behavior-based interview questions

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Mar 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer is nice and friendly. Asked a bunch questions, including behavior ones. The whole process lasted about two hours. We basically talked about everything covering technical questions, background, and behavior questions.
Interview Questions: How do you like university of Michigan? Describe a scenario where you consider as difficult in life, and how do you overcome that?

title: Development Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Received an email about a week after applying on the website, asking me to complete an extensive essay-type online survey that addressed typical issues on personality, work habits, attitudes, writing ability, and character.
About a week later I received an email invitation from an HR coordinator to interview with an HR recruiter. I asked how I could prepare for the interview and was told to read the department website, which I did, and thought I had as good a grasp of the organization’s business as any outsider who had not done the job previously. 
The interview, a week later, was cordial. The fact that the job I applied for promised to pay less than the salary I had earned in a term-limited temp position that had lasted 11 months at another university seemed to strike the interviewer as strange...as if there were no reason a person should seek a lower-paying job in a recession. I sensed that the recruiter was more interested in finding reasons to screen me out as a candidate than to explore how I might be able to help the organization. 
I had the feeling that an outsider applicant faced a significant acceptance hurdle in comparison to insider applicants, maybe in part because the job descriptions the university posts online mean something very different to insiders than to outsiders, and partly because there is a highly inbred culture there into which it is almost impossible to assimilate as an outsider with no background as a graduate or at least an employee who had worked there four years or more. Career-changers from other industries, regardless of experience and skills, don’t seem welcome, and the heavy emphasis on diversity doesn’t yet mean inclusiveness for people over 50.
I received a call from the interviewer about a week later to tell me that I had not been selected for the next round, which would have been an interview with the hiring manager. I appreciated the personal touch in that regard because I’ve not found it to be typical in the recruitment industry, where non-communication with applicants has become the standard of service.
Interview Questions: Pre-interview essay: Relate a difficult situation you faced at work and how you dealt with it.

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview

title: Web Applications Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Aug 2011

I was contacted after applying on the internal jobs board. I was interviewed by two people simultaneously, both of which were to be my direct superiors. It was clear that neither of them had any experience hiring or managing personnel. There were no difficult questions--mostly just about my skills and experience. I was asked if I had any sample work, which I produced on the spot and allowed them to view. They both played around with a few demos, staying pretty much silent. Afterwards, they had no questions or comments.

After the interview, I received an unprofessionally worded email saying that I had been passed over for another candidate. A few days later, I got another email saying that their desired candidate had declined the position and asking if I would still be interested. It left a bad taste in my mouth, but I took the job anyway.
Interview Questions:
What kind of experience do you have?
What do you know about Drupal?

title: Performance Support Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jul 2011
Interview Descriptions:
I am looking for a niche position, difficult to state in a few words, so when I find a listing that looks very interesting, I apply.  The University of Michigan is still a wonderful place to work andn offers so much opportunity, it's a natural choice.

The U of M website is nicely organized for applicants to upload and retain resumes for a variety of positions.  One difference compared to other company websites is that they request you have a cover letter as page 1 of the resume, saved as one complete document, rather than a separate cover letter document.  That makes applying a bit more time-consuming than on other company sites, but certainly worth the effort.

I applied for this position via the U of M website and was contacted within a week to schedule a phone interview with the hiring manager (team lead of the group to which I had applied).  The phone interview was an hour long and I was impressed that the manager asked a wide variety of questions, not just the typical "HR" ones ... for instance, we talked about what I appreciate in a work environment, what stresses me out when working on a team - questions that dug into my motivation, values and real interests that attracted me to this position.

Within a few days I was scheduled for a group interview that would include giving a presentation, group Q&A and a few types of skills tests.  That interview was quite enjoyable - just the right mx of professional and personal interaction.  I could see the dedication these folks held toward their roles in this department and at the U, and I felt at home with these possible new coworkers.  Some "HR" style questions, descibe a situation and how you handled it, etc, plus more of the "what do you value" questions that I find so encouraging (a job is more than a paycheck to me).  All told, with applying, research, all interview time and preparation, I probably put about 12 hours toward this position (that's why I am rating the interview "difficult").

It took about 2 more weeks to hear that I was not selected for the position.  I have no complaints about this whole experience - other than not getting the job, I guess! - it was conducted with a great degree of care and professionalism.  They worked closely with me to explore the possibilities, which is all I could have asked for; in the end, they just felt I was not as ideal a candidate as someone else.  I have asked for more feedback on where I fell short, or any other constructive criticism ... even if I don't hear back on that aspect, knowing I was given consideration helps me keep defining my own ideal niche position!
Interview Questions: What would your boss at your last job say are your strengths and weaknesses?

title: Admissions Counselor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jul 2010
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online in May 2010 for the position. I received a call from HR in June 2010 asking me a few questions, but focused on whether or not I would be ok with the incredibly low salary. She stated that there would be no room for negotiations period. After I said ok, she scheduled me for a panel interview of directors for the following week. I was to bring a list of improvements for there website to the interview for their review. I did so & the panel interview seemed to go great. During the interview, I was asked to do an on the spot 60 second sell of the school. Good thing I'd done a lot of research on the school and had a lot of good points memorized, so I did well on that too. Immediately after the interview, I was taken to a computer and required to compose an email that was being timed at 30 minutes. I must have passed because a week later I got a call for the second interview.

At the second interview, which was also a panel, but of different directors, I was asked similar behavioral questions as before. However, there were some trick questions included, like "what are your weaknesses?", which I answered as being a compassionate person and concerned about helping as much as I can. For which, it was replied that it was a concern about if I could adequately do the job, because it would be necessary to be stand-offish and maybe cold when explaining that a student would not be accepted. I was a little thrown by questions like that, but I remained composed. At the end of the second interview, I was required to do a 10 minute presentation selling the school to students with no visual aids. This was something that was told to me ahead of time that I would have to do, so I studied pretty hard for it. It was a little discouraging that one of the directors seemed disinterested and bored during my presentation, but all you can give is all that you have.

There 4 positions open. I was told when they were planning to be hired by and when they planned to start the orientation for the new hires. I also filled out paperwork for a background check on my degrees, driver's record (which has no points), etc. and I gave them my references.

I received an email 2 weeks after the 2nd interview saying that they filled the positions. The process was very detailed and involved and for me and to not be offered any of the positions was pretty disappointing. I did learn that once you are called for a position, that means you are qualified for the job. At that point, I believe, it is all about whether they like your personality or if you fit into a preconceived image in their minds. I think I did well in every aspect of the process, but I did get the feeling that they didn't think I would "fit" into their environment, though I wasn't sure why. You can only be you and be the best you that you can be.
Interview Questions: We are high school seniors. In 60 seconds, sell the school to us.

The interview process included a phone call and email follow up confirming the date of the first meeting. A group/panel interview takes place at the employer work place; this is the skills and technical interview. If you are considered for a second interview you will be notified and you will be meeting a group of end users and not so technical personnel. There is a third meeting to review salary and other aspects of the hiring process.

In the overall process there is always good communication either if you are or not considered for the next interview.

You are treated with respect and everybody seems to be enjoying their work.
Interview Questions: Could you tell us about a time when you made a mistake and how did you handle it?

title: Neuroscience Graduate Student Interview

Interview Questions: I really didn't have any difficult or unexpected question. We talked about science and we all enjoyed our time spent talking.

title: Clinical Subjects Coordinator Interview
Application Type: The process took 5 days. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Jan 2010
Interview Descriptions: What a WEIRD interview! I should start this by saying that I have rarely failed to land either a second interview that I declined, or a job after an interview (not to be cocky - I don't always GET interviews, but when I get them I tend to do pretty well). I found a job that was perfect for my skills and qualifications, basically something I thought I was extremely qualified for, credential-wise. Honestly, I'd never found a job that fit my skills and interests so well. So after applying, I waited about 4 months to hear back. I'd written them off at that point, but when they called to set up an interview I went along with it. I didn't receive any of the emails they said they sent confirming time or location, but I knew where they were so it wasn't a big problem. Once I got to the interview, though,  things got... strange. I met with a few people at the scheduled time. I was asked two questions, total: 1) What did I think the qualifications of this position would be (and did I have them); and 2) what role did I have in my research abstracts. The tone of the second question seemed to imply that maybe I hadn't done what I said I had, which I really didn't appreciate in a prospective future team. The whole thing lasted literally about 20 minutes (after they'd told me to block an hour). They didn't ask when I was available to start or if I had salary requirements or anything (although they told me they were going to choose a candidate soon) and they were sort of short when I asked questions, and didn't do the typical "any other questions?" bit -- in fact, it seems like they were resisting questions. I couldn't tell walking out whether they'd had a candidate in mind the whole time but had to do the superficial interviewing of qualified candidates, or if they just disliked me on sight, but it was clear I was not getting a job with them. It's also possible that I was overqualified (turns out the job was much lower level than they had described in the initial posting), or who knows what else. Anyway, it was probably the strangest interview I've ever had. I never heard that the position was closed, either. Overall, given the lag time between the job open/close date and when they called me, I feel like there was probably an element of mandatory interviewing involved, but I was a little resentful that they would spend my time knowing that they weren't interested in me as a candidate going in. I could be wrong and maybe it was something I did, but I don't really feel like the interview lasted long enough for me to blow it. Who knows...
Interview Questions: What do you think the skills needed to be successful at this job are, and do you have them?

title: Clinical Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions:
Online application was painless, but not very well organized. Then you wait... and wait... and wait...  If you are not selected, you will not know anything until after the position is officially filled. The you will get an email stating such. If you are lucky enough to get an interview, you will usually get an email invitation to call and schedule an appointment for a phone screen or initial 1:1 within a 1-2 month window. After another wait of 1-2 weeks, a group interview or series of individual interviews will occur.  Then you wait... and wait... and wait...  If they choose you, you will get a follow up call to discuss the low-ball salary that you will be offered. If they don't choose you, you will eventually get the same email as referenced above. 

The big message here is to have extreme patience. Forget any hope for a quick response and remember that almost every posting gets several dozen responses and thus is highly competitive.
Interview Questions: What was the number one growth area listed on your last performance review?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Atlanta, GA) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: It was not easy to get hold of the supervisor as he held a high posting at the Emory school of medicine and met up with his lab members once a week. After 3 weeks of attending his lab meetings, I was given an opportunity to present my doctoral work. I was able to also come up with some probable research that I could do at his lab and he immediately seemed pleased and offered me the post doctoral position soon after the lab meeting
Interview Questions: Why didn't you try te yeast two hybrid system to determine interaction between domains and other standard technical questions that were not difficult to answer

title: Senior Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: Judging by the questions, the interviewers were looking for admistrative experience only, not Business Analysis skills. There were 4 interviewers, over 3 interviews. The interviewers did not have Business Analysis background, they were all business managers with no actual IT background. They did not clearly define the position, authority, and responsibilities. There was a different definition during each interview, and by each interviewer. The questions were pre-written and standard behavioral interview questions (For example: :Describe a time when you had to resolve a conflict"). It was obvious that not all the interviewers had seen the questions before. It was also obvious that they were looking more for someone "like them" then for a certain skillset.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a decision process was not progressing?
